message: Wishing everyone a 2017 full of peace, good health and happiness. -------Deseandole a todos un 2017 lleno de paz, buena salud y felicidad.

A 20 year old conviction for turnstile jumping or another minor infraction should not lead to deportation. Without action, individuals with minor violations on their records could be forced to go back to a country they do not know and they may be separated from their spouses and children- leading to unnecessary emotional and economic harm.  President Obama has previously used his executive authority to deprioritize the deportation of these individuals- but I've just led a letter with my colleague Representative Nydia Velázquez asking that he use his pardon powers to ensure their safety and security beyond January 20th: http://bit.ly/2joOuNz
The Serrano Report for this week with information about my work in Congress & The Bronx is available online at: go.usa.gov/x9EZh

Today President Obama announced that he was using his Presidential pardon powers to commute the sentence of #OscarLopez, a Puerto Rican independence activist who has been imprisoned for over 35 years. All Puerto Ricans have been united on the need to bring Oscar home, and I want to express my gratitude to President Obama for listening to the thousands of voices- from all over our nation and the world - that asked for clemency.     Hoy el Presidente Obama anunció que utilizará su poder de otorgar un perdón presidencial para liberar a #OscarLopez, un activista independentista puertorriqueño que ha estado en prisión por más de 35 años. Toda la comunidad puertorriqueña ha estado unida en el reclamo de liberar a Oscar, y quiero aprovechar este momento para darle las gracias al Presidente Obama por escuchar las miles de voces, dentro de la nación americana y alrededor del mundo, que clamaron por clemencia.

The White House website keeps citizens informed about the actions undertaken by the President, as well as the executive branch policies and initiatives. That is why I find it disturbing that the Trump administration took down its Spanish-language version upon entering office, which will make it harder for the over 40 million native Spanish speakers that reside in the US to be informed about our government’s actions. Our Hispanic population’s needs and concerns have to be addressed; removing Spanish from our government’s website without having a suitable replacement ready is a clear indication that the Trump administration does not care about all Americans.   ---------------------------------   La página web de la Casa Blanca mantiene informados a nuestros ciudadanos sobre las acciones del Presidente, además de las iniciativas y la política pública de la rama ejecutiva. Es por esto que me perturba el saber que la administración de Trump eliminó la sección en español de la página web, haciendo más difícil el que los más de 40 millones de habitantes hispanoparlantes que residen en los Estados Unidos se mantengan informados acerca de las acciones de nuestro gobierno. Las preocupaciones y necesidades de la comunidad hispana tienen que ser resueltas; el quitar el español de la página web de nuestro gobierno sin tener un reemplazo disponible es una señal clara de que a la administración de Trump no le importan todos los americanos.

He served in the NY Assembly, NY State Senate and the U.S. Congress. He was involved in many issues that affected our community. R.I.P. my friend.

As the deadline to #GetCovered with #ACA health insurance approaches we want to make sure you know all of the resources that are available. If you live in New York city please visit www.nystateofhealth.ny.gov to get information on how to sign-up.   You can also visit https://info.nystateofhealth.ny.gov/events to see a calendar of community events where you can #GetCoveredNYC. If you need help with the enrollment process you can also visit https://info.nystateofhealth.ny.gov/IPANavigatorSiteLocations to make an appointment with an In-Person Assistors.   Please remember to get covered before the January 31st, 2017 deadline. Individuals not enrolled will face fines of up to $695 per adult and $347 per child.

La fecha límite de inscripción para el #ACA es el 31 de Enero de 2017, y queremos asegurarnos que nuestros constituyentes tengan la información adecuada para realizar el trámite. Si vives en Nueva York por favor visita la página web https://nystateofhealth.ny.gov/individual?lang=es para obtener información en español.   También puede visitar la página web https://info.nystateofhealth.ny.gov/events para ver un calendario de eventos comunitarios en donde puede inscribirse en un plan de seguro médico. Si necesita asistencia para el proceso de inscripción puede hacer una cita con un representante en persona a través de este link https://info.nystateofhealth.ny.gov/IPANavigatorSiteLocations,  para que una persona adiestrada en el proceso de inscripción le brinde ayuda.   Por favor recuerde inscribirse antes de Enero 31 del 2017. Individuos que no estén cubierto por el #ACA luego de esa fecha podrían enfrentar una multa de $695 por adulto, y $347 por niño.

The executive orders issued by @potus are full of hate and bigotry. We must all oppose them. Discrimination against Muslims is not constitutional. These executive orders go against everything we stand for as a great nation.

Today I joined House Democrats in co-sponsoring the Statue of Liberty Values (SOLVE) Act that would rescind the executive order signed by President Trump establishing a unconstitutional #MuslimBan in the United States. Our country is built on the values of tolerance and diversity, and places like the Bronx would not be what they are today without the contributions of immigrants, refugees, and Muslim-Americans.  The Trump administration’s executive order threatens to destroy that proud tradition in the name of national security.   In the wake of this announcement, people from all across the political spectrum, including thousands of protestors, have made it clear that our country should not turn its back on the people that need it the most. As a member of the Appropriations committee I will do everything in my power to make sure government funds are not used to carry out this immoral and illegal executive order. #RefugeesWelcome
Standing with @HouseDemocrats and refugees against @POTUS #MuslimBan at the Supreme Court

Today I led 38 House Democrats in sending a letter to the Department of Homeland Security Inspector General and their Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties calling for comprehensive investigations into reports of the potential abuse of civil rights & constitutional rights perpetrated by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officers during the implementation of President Trump's #MuslimBan Executive Order.   The reports indicate that C.B.P. officials denied detainees access to legal representation, and coerced visa holders and Legal Permanent Residents into signing documents that would relinquish their legal immigration status. If the reports are accurate the actions undertaken by these officers undermine important provisions of our Constitution and the rule of law in the United States.   That is why we are asking these two offices to investigate these reports so that individuals that acted illegally can be held accountable, and to ensure that our immigration system is administered in a fair, impartial, and constitutional manner.  You can read the letter here: http://bit.ly/2k8fZu2

Yesterday the #9thCircuitCourtOfAppeals maintained the freeze on the unconstitutional #MuslimBan ordered by the Trump administration. With this ruling our justice system made sure that justice and our Constitution prevailed.  There will be more court cases on this issue- and we will be ready to continue fighting against bigotry.

Today I was heartened to see Democrats and Republicans offer testimony in support of programs that are rumored to be targeted for spending cuts like the COPS program, the Legal Services Corporation, and funding for the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA). Republicans and Democrats in Congress alike made it clear that gutting spending in important social and economic programs is a non-starter in Congress. http://bit.ly/2l8SBlh

Last week, I, along with several of my colleagues in the NYC Congressional Delegation, sent a letter to the NYC Department of Education seeking answers and clarification on the City’s response to high lead levels in our public schools. Lead exposure is not something to take lightly. It seriously puts our children’s health and development at risk. The City must be fully transparent with the findings of their investigations; notify all parents- regardless of language- about the situation; and provide a timeline for immediately addressing contaminated water systems or infrastructure. All of our children deserve to have access to a safe, lead-free learning environment. Read more here: http://bit.ly/2mmMNo4

I was thrilled to hear that NOAA has included the #HudsonCanyon in its inventory of sites being considered for National Marine Sanctuary status. This past November, I led 13 Members of Congress in sending a letter to NOAA asking for them to take this step. The designation of the Canyon as a National Marine Sanctuary will help ensure that the canyon’s resources are utilized in a sustainable manner that protects its biodiversity, and allows visitors to enjoy this marine treasure for generations to come. I want to thank the local elected officials, private sector stakeholders, and environmental groups who helped make this possible. Read more here: http://bit.ly/2mUPYAe
R.I.P. #MiriamColon a pioneer and giant in our community. Her career included close to 100 films & 250 TV appearances. Founder of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater. #legacy

I am deeply troubled by Congressional Republican’s plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. The “so-called American Health Care Act” will cause 20 million Americans, including 400,000 in the Bronx, to lose coverage by phasing out the vital Medicaid expansion and re-engineering tax credits that will once again put low-income and working class Americans at a disadvantage from accessing affordable care. The age-based tax credits also openly discriminate against older Americans who use health care more frequently. Americans who have pre-existing conditions will once again have insurance companies cut off access to care once they reach their lifetime insurance limit. The graphic below shows how negatively my constituents will be impacted by this proposal. As your member of Congress, I will fight to protect Medicaid expansion, subsidies to make coverage more affordable, and the invaluable consumer protections under the ACA.
The GOP’s health care bill is a #RxForDisaster for America’s families!

President Trump is considering a proposal to cut HUD’s budget by $6 billion dollars. This is an insult to the moral character of our nation. HUD funds many programs across the country that assist the homeless and low income individuals that cannot afford housing without assistance. This cut would potentially leave many vulnerable Americans out in the streets. President Trump promised the American people that he would help low-income communities and this proposal would do the complete opposite. If this is included in his final budget proposal then I will make sure to do everything within my capacity to prevent its implementation by the Appropriations Committee. #HUDCut

According to the new report by the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) #24Million individuals will lose their health coverage if Trump's healthcare plan gets passed into law. Yet another example of a Trump policy that lowers the quality of life for everyday Americans.

Yesterday, Republicans attacked the credibility of a nonpartisan analysis that showed the Republicans’ #RxForDisaster bill would kick 24 million Americans off their health care. Now, we’re learning that the White House’s internal numbers show that number is actually 26 million. The hypocrisy is astounding! https://goo.gl/mEXvmK

The #budget proposed by the Trump administration guts agencies that work to protect the environment, defend our civil rights, and that help businesses expand. Just to build a wall. I cannot support a budget that chooses to fund war & exclusion at the expense of working families all across the United States.

Looks like the President is not quite the skilled negotiator that he claims to be and Republicans can’t even agree on how to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. We should be glad that Speaker Ryan and Republicans had to abandon their bill to kill #Obamacare and that it got nowhere in the House.  I vehemently opposed this legislation because it would have kicked 24 million Americans- including nearly 130,000 #Bronxites in my district- off their health care, increased health care costs, and rolled back many of the hard fought consumer protections in the ACA. Thank you to all the constituents who called my office to voice your support. I will continue to do all I can as your Member of Congress to protect and expand access to health care, and work to bring down costs so all Americans have equal access to care.

I am disappointed to hear the remarks of Attorney General Jeff Sessions regarding efforts to  withhold funds for #SanctuaryCities. Using $4 billion in funding to hold these cities hostage will not make America safer, nor will it help improve the relationship between the local police and the community they serve. For decades the position of the Republican Party has been to give more power and flexibility to local and state governments so they can develop policies that are better suited for the communities they represent.  Forcing local police officers to work for ICE is a direct contradiction of those values, and will make our communities less safe.  As the top Democrat on the appropriations subcommittee that oversees Department of Justice funding, I plan to oppose the AG’s efforts.

Today, along with Rep. Espaillat, Rep. Bonamici, and Rep. Beyer, I introduced the Protecting Sensitive Locations Act. This bill’s purpose is to designate places like schools, healthcare facilities, churches, and government offices as “Sensitive zones” that will be protected from #ICE raids. No one in the US should be fearful of taking their children to school, receiving medical care, or going to their place of worship. The #SensitiveLocationsAct creates common-sense limits to ensure that ICE agents perform their duties in a way that protects the safety, health, and civil rights of immigrants. It will also help preserve the security in our communities by helping ensure immigrants are not afraid to visit a court, report crimes and engage with law enforcement institutions and officials in other ways.     Hoy, junto a los Congresistas Espaillat, Bonamici, y Beyer, presenté el proyecto de ley “Protecting Sensitive Locations Act”. De convertirse en ley, el #SensitiveLocationsAct designaría a hospitales, escuelas, iglesias, y oficinas de gobierno como lugares sensitivos en donde agentes de #ICE no podrían llevar a cabo operativos. Nadie que viva en los Estados Unidos debería de sentir temor de ser deportado al llevar a sus hijos a la escuela, ir a facilidades médicas, o asistir a la iglesia. Este proyecto de ley crea limites bajo la ley para asegurar que los agentes de ICE conduzcan su trabajo de una manera que proteja la seguridad, la salud, y los derechos civiles de los inmigrantes. También ayudará a preservar la seguridad en nuestras comunidades al ayudar a asegurar que los inmigrantes no tengan miedo de visitar un tribunal, reportar crímenes y relacionarse con instituciones u oficiales de la ley de otras formas.

50 years ago #MLKJr spoke these words in his "Beyond Vietnam: A Time to Break the Silence" speech at Riverside Church in New York City. And they still ring true. Just a year later, to the day, we would lose Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. to racially-motivated violence   Today, on the 50th Anniversary of his "Beyond Vietnam" speech, I am proud to join my colleagues in sponsoring a resolution that commemorates MLK, Jr's sermon.
The Serrano Report for this week with information about my work in congress & in The Bronx is available online at: bit.ly/2ohPWWZ

I introduced the Sewage Sludge in Food Production Consumer Notification Act. If the bill becomes law it would require the food industry to label products that have been grown in farmlands that use sewage sludge as fertilizer. Americans need to know where and how their food was grown so that they can make informed decisions when buying food products, especially if the fertilizer used to grow that food contains varying degrees of pathogens, heavy metals, organic chemicals, industrial solvents, asbestos, and radioactive waste. It is time to make sure that federal law adequately protects consumers from sewage sludge that is being used as fertilizer.
Wishing you a very happy and peaceful Passover.

The announcement by the Department of Justice that it will allocate more funding for prosecuting immigration crimes in federal court is another attempt by the Trump administration to demonize the immigrant community living in the United States. By prioritizing immigration crimes, the DOJ is taking limited resources away from fraud, terrorism, and gun trafficking cases which have a greater impact in the safety and well-being of all American families. Already 52% of federal prosecutions are immigration cases, this unnecessary directive will only result in the misguided use of our very limited resources.

On this day, April 15,1947, #JackieRobinson became the first African American to play Major League Baseball. A courageous and talented pioneer who made baseball and our great country much better.  #HallofFame-------------------------------------  En esta fecha Abril 15, del 1947 Jackie Robinson se convirtió en el primer Afro Americano de jugar baseball en las grandes ligas. Con su talento y forma de ser no sólo cambió el baseball pero también cambio a esta  gran nación para siempre. #SalondelaFama

Yesterday, Earth Day, I visited The Get Green South Bronx Earth Fest at St. Mary's Park in the #Bronx. The fact that there is a Beaver named Jose as part of my work on the @BronxRiver cleanup was mentioned.  I was humbled by the recognition. But there was another great surprise. I was asked to take a seat as singer/songwriter, Terri Bocklund, sang her song in tribute to Jose The Beaver. "Boggie Down Beaver". It was a great moment and I was honored by it all. Thanks to John Johnson, Janna from Grow NYC.  A great event for all.

Today I met with Tiffany Yee Vo, UAW Columbia University Lead Organizer and Olga Brudastova, PhD Student in Civil Engineering at Columbia University. They both came to the office to discuss the importance of unionization efforts in higher education throughout NYC. Great cause and great meeting. I totally support their efforts.

Today I met with members from the New York State Bar Association to discuss how we can make sure that the Legal Services Corporation (LSC) is funded in order for them to continue their work protecting the most vulnerable in our justice system. As the Senior Democrat on the Appropriations subcommittee that funds the LSC, I am committed to ensuring that local legal services providers have the money they need to ensure that all Americans, regardless of wealth, can have their day in court.

I met with members from the National Association of Latino Arts and Cultures to discuss the importance of funding the National Endowment for the Arts, as well as the National Endowment for the Humanities, so that our country can keep investing in the development of the arts and our artists.

I had the opportunity to sit down and talk with students from Claremont International High School in #TheBronx. We spoke about what Congress can do to help improve the quality of life for future generations and how young people can become involved in their community.

Congressman Adriano Espaillat and I sent a letter today to the Secretary of Education, Betsy De Vos, to ask for an explanation on the Department’s decision to deny funding for the Upward Bound program proposals submitted by Fordham University and Columbia University. For decades, the #UpwardBound program at both universities has helped thousands of low-income high school students prepare to enter and successfully complete college, and shutting down this program without a valid reason is not only shameful, but a direct attack on our students who deserve better

Glad to be part of the opening ceremonies of the Castle Hill Baseball Little League. Coaches, parents & volunteers doing a great job with our youth. This is one of the best organized and most successful programs for our youth.

The just announced Omnibus Appropriations bill includes funding to reimburse New York City for the costs of protecting Donald Trump and his family while they reside at Trump Tower.  As a senior appropriator on the Committee, this was a top priority for me, and I fought to ensure that New York was able to recoup these unprecedented costs.  This was a matter of fairness for New Yorkers- we shouldn’t have to bear the full cost of protecting the President and his family at Trump Tower– and with this funding, we won’t have to.

I sent a letter today along with Rep. Nydia  Velazquez to the Chairman of Puerto Rico’s Fiscal Control Board urging the Board caution that austerity measures are not taken too far and to prioritize economic recovery. Puerto Rico's fiscal crisis should not be used as an excuse to take away worker's rights. Unfortunately, local legislative measures being proposed in Puerto Rico - including one that ends dues deductions for public sector workers - threaten to weaken long held union protections in order to solve a problem that does not exist. Taking away workers’ rights to support the implementation of austerity measures is not the way to develop the island's economy to get out of the crisis. These changes will greatly hurt unions’ ability to organize, protect workers, and collectively bargain.  Unions were not the cause of the island's crisis, and they should not be used as a scapegoat. _________________________________________________________________________________________________________     La crisis fiscal de Puerto Rico no debe de ser utilizada para eliminarles derechos a los trabajadores. Lamentablemente algunas medidas legislativas que han sido presentadas en Puerto Rico – incluyendo una que elimina la deducción automática de las cuotas a empleados públicos unionados – amenazan con debilitar a las uniones para “resolver” un problema que no existe. Eliminar derechos a empleados públicos para continuar con la implementación de medidas de austeridad no es la manera adecuada de desarrollar la economía de la isla y terminar con la crisis. Estos cambios van a impactar negativamente la habilidad de las uniones de organizar y proteger a los trabajadores. Las uniones no tienen la culpa de la crisis fiscal así que no deberían de ser utilizados como chivo expiatorio.

With record-breaking temperatures and abnormal weather patterns occurring each year, the overwhelming scientific consensus on climate change is undeniable. Climate change affects all nations around the world and a global solution like the #ParisAgreement is the only way to successfully address this threat. I am disturbed by reports that the president plans to withdraw the United States from this international accord, thereby ceding American leadership and further alienating our allies around the world. Coastal communities like The Bronx and New York City will be devastated by the impacts of climate change. This threat affects our national security, economy, and way of life. I urge the president to do the right thing by remaining part of the agreement and leading the charge against climate change on the world stage.

Today I introduced the Public Housing Capital Repair Fund Act. This bill will provide funding to public housing authorities like @NYCHA so that they can address much-needed capital repairs that will make public housing safer for millions of Americans across the country. In NYC alone Mayor DeBlasio estimates that the health of over 400,000 individuals  is threatened by the lack of funding to improve public housing conditions. These investments in long-term repair projects will have a positive, measurable, and immediate impact in the health and well-being of hundreds of families. We cannot wait any more to fix the unacceptable housing conditions that pose a health hazard to public housing residents.

Today, the New York Times reported that the Trump Administration’s Justice Department political appointees at the Civil Rights Division are preparing to take action against universities’ Affirmative Action policies and practices based on the claim that they discriminate against white applicants. Not only is this effort based on a distortion of facts that ignores our nation’s history, it threatens to undermine educational opportunity and represents an affront on our nation’s values. Inclusive and diverse higher education environments contribute to educational quality by guaranteeing students are exposed to a wide range of experiences, opinions and ideas. For generations, students that previously wouldn’t have had access to quality higher education have been able to achieve what their parents or grandparents couldn’t and/or enjoy the benefits of having a richer experience while at college.  This effort also undermines the very mission of the Civil Rights Division, and it is speaks volumes that career employees- dedicated to helping protect those historically marginalized- are being excluded from this effort.  I strongly oppose efforts to undo years of progress that we have made as a nation in expanding access to higher education to historically underrepresented groups.

The #RaiseAct, an extreme anti-immigrant proposal presented by Republican Senators Tom Cotton (R-AR) and David Perdue (R-GA) in the Senate and supported by President Trump, targets legal migration in a way that would restrict entry into our nation by separating families; eliminating important visa programs; and hurting important American businesses’ and industries’ capacity to hire talent and remain competitive. This proposal is especially harmful to the Bronx- where immigrants from the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Nigeria, Ghana and elsewhere would be greatly harmed by these changes.  I oppose this bill and urge Republicans to propose sensible, common sense solutions to comprehensively fix our immigration system instead of out of touch ideas that attack our nation's diversity.

Today marks the 5th year anniversary of DACA and now more than ever we must unite to #DefendDACA. This program has helped over 800,000 young people – all of whom have spent the vast majority of their lives in the United States and call our country home-- complete their studies and work legally without the fear of deportation. Their presence and work greatly contributes to the economic growth of the #Bronx, New York City, and the nation as a whole. But any moment, Donald Trump could eliminate #DACA. In June, ten state attorney generals sent a letter to Attorney General Jeff Sessions asking him to abolish the program and former Homeland Security Secretary Kelly himself has indicated that the program is at risk of being ended unless Congress takes action.  I will continue to work in Congress to ensure that #Dreamers have access to full protection under the law to be able to work, study and fully contribute to their communities and our country.

@repjoecrowley and I sent a letter to the National Science Foundation (NSF) to inquire on how they plan to implement their new Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI) grant program.  As Senior Democrat on the subcommittee that funds the National Science Foundation, I funded this program for the first time last year.  We need speedy and detailed implementation of this grant program to ensure Hispanics interested in STEM fields can access the tools they need to succeed in those fields. Read the full press release and letter here: https://goo.gl/JxkwXF

@RepNydiaVelazquez and I recently sent a letter to the Chairman of the Financial Oversight and Management Board for Puerto Rico, Mr. José B. Carrión, calling for more transparency on expenses and disbursements.  The board has spent over $30 million in their first year of operations, an amount that is alarming and concerning. We urge the Chairman and the Board to be transparent and accountable with the money they spend. The people of Puerto Rico as taxpayers are the ones footing the bill; they have the right and deserve to know how the money is being spent. The letter provides suggestions that they can use to accurately track and disclose disbursements like we do in Congress.

After 16 years in Afghanistan, we have seen few signs of success and still no clear strategy.  We should not once again increase the number of troops being put in harm’s way for the vague plan announced by the President. We should bring the rest of our troops home- as Donald Trump promised during the campaign.  Beyond that, it is long past time for Congress to once again debate the authorization for the use of military force in Afghanistan- we have ceded our role to the executive branch for too long.

Republican’s latest attempt to repeal the #AffordableCareAct (#Obamacare) is even worse than their previous efforts. It would leave millions of Americans without affordable health insurance, gut key patient protections, cause premiums to skyrocket, and steal from Medicaid. I have and will continue to fight against these efforts to gut the Affordable Care Act and I urge you to call Republican Senators and Representatives to ask that they oppose this irresponsible bill.

Puerto Rico has been devastated by Hurricane Maria, and the pictures that have been published out of the island are heartbreaking. As a senior Member of the Appropriations Committee, I will be working with my colleagues on the committee to quickly craft a comprehensive emergency disaster supplemental that addresses the rebuilding and recovery process in areas impacted by Hurricanes Maria, Irma, and Harvey. It is imperative that we provide robust disaster response funding to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Read my full statement here: http://bit.ly/2fdrbpf

We need a comprehensive federal response to respond to the disaster created by Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico.  As a New Yorker, I remain grateful for the wide-ranging federal funding that helped us recover from Superstorm Sandy- and a similar response is needed here.  From environmental disasters to health care to housing- the damage done to Puerto Rico is enormous, and we need to address all sectors.  FEMA is there to help with the immediate emergency, but there also needs to be a long term plan. That is why I, along with Congresswoman Velazquez, Resident Commissioner Gonzalez-Colon, and Congressman Soto, sent a letter to the President to quickly establish a task force to help plan the recovery.  This is what President Obama did after Sandy- and we need to do the same here. http://bit.ly/2jRugQP

My heart goes out to all of the victims of the tragedy in #LasVegas, the deadliest shooting in US History – more than 50 people dead and at least 400 injured so far.  Mass shootings are becoming all too common- and we need to ask ourselves some serious questions about gun violence in our nation.  We need a serious conversation on common-sense solutions to prevent tragic events like this one- including limitations on the types of guns that individuals can purchase. Moments of silence will not help prevent this from happening and I urge my colleagues on both aisles to address this issue in an urgent manner.

Led letter with 83 of my colleagues to @homelandsecurity on Sensitive Locations Policy violations by officers at Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection (CBP). ICE and CBP should not target vulnerable immigrant families at sensitive locations such as hospitals and schools, and their own policies say the same.  Unfortunately, since January, there have been reports that they are undermining the health, safety, and welfare of immigrants by conducting raids at these locations. Our immigrant communities should not live in constant fear. Read the full letter and press release here: http://bit.ly/2guPccj

Today, I joined House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi and other Democratic colleagues to once again call for more aid for Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. The Trump Administration’s funding request for relief efforts post-hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico fails to provide sufficient funding to help Puerto Rico address immediate needs and set itself on the road to recovery. We also understand that it fails to provide a solution to the potentially devastating Medicaid cliff that is currently facing Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.  Moving forward without significant changes will only hinder the Puerto Rican government’s capacity to address the situation on the ground and will contribute to further suffering on the island. The @FCC's decision to repeal Net Neutrality is devastating to our nation’s freedom of speech. I will continue to oppose this decision and encourage everyone to keep fighting for a free internet. The battle is not over.

Recently sent out a letter to @NYCMayor with my Bronx colleagues, @repjoecrowley @RepEspaillat and @RepEliotEngel, to urge him to prioritize #LGBTQ community needs in his upcoming term. The Bronx is the only borough in New York City without a much needed LGBTQ community center. Read the full letter and our statements here: http://bit.ly/2zkW0TE

The @GOP's Disaster Supplemental does not do enough to address the needs of Puerto Rico & the US Virgin Islands after Hurricane Maria. It creates a larger financial burden for their recovery efforts, and does nothing to address the looming Medicaid cliff. It doesn’t help states that have welcomed Puerto Ricans, and it doesn’t provide enough to ensure Puerto Rico can quickly recover.  Republicans could have worked with Democrats to address some of these issues, but they chose not to. This is unacceptable and I oppose this bill and this process. Read my full statement here: http://bit.ly/2BfXyRG

Congratulations to my friend and fellow New Yorker @RepJerryNadler on becoming the new Ranking Democrat of @HouseJudiciary. It is a pivotal time in our history and we need allies like Jerry to seek justice for all in our country.

The Disaster Supplemental only provides $81 billion to be split between Texas, Florida, California, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Puerto Rico's governor asked for $94 billion. This supplemental is clearly not enough to help the local government and 3.5 million Americans who live on the island fully recover in the aftermath of the worst natural disaster in its history. It creates a larger financial burden for their recovery efforts, and does nothing to address the looming Medicaid cliff. Republicans could have worked with Democrats to address some of these issues, but they chose not to. This is unacceptable, I will vote NO on this bill and will continue pushing for additional aid for Puerto Rico and the territories. Watch my full remarks here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AWyE5I2O5Zk&feature=youtu.be
